content:
Nice clash.

Validator 3 gives a very annoying issue in Ruby, and maybe some other languages. Ruby finds that the net moment is -2.842170943040401e-14 due to float arithmetic errors. :(
I got 80% in my clash because none of the test cases had such an issue... Not sure the best way to fix this, since it's hard to know what tests will give float arithmetic issues in which languages, but it would be nice if there was a test that threw such an error rather than just a validator, so clashers could debug this in-clash. (My code shared in comment below).

Another smaller issue is that you ask us to display the answer with units "N" but moment has units "Nm".

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I couldn't resolve it in less five minutes but i like this puzzle. I'm sure good developpers could do it.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very detailed description, and great physics.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: with the round to integer it's much simple....i think it's a good puzzle

your solution code doesn't works the validator 2 with the round after the difference between anti-clockwise and clockwise moments.

to make it clear, your code:
# Round to 2dp. 
anti_clockwise = round(anti_clockwise , 2)
clockwise = round(clockwise , 2)
then you check the relationship between anti_clockwise and clockwise 

the solution does't work if i do
net_moment= round(anti_clockwise - clockwise, 2)
and then check if net_moment==0, net_moment>0 or net_moment<0


because your Output format: "Line 2: Net moment acting on the beam (rounded to 2 d.p.)... " i assumed that the round was done to the net moment, NOT the ANTI-CLOCKWISE moment and the CLOCKWISE moment.


must we change how the Net moment is defined?

Goal
* Please change "a [[identifier]]" to "an [[identifier]]".

* Suggest to simplify the second formula as follows, similar to how you present the first formula:

â€¢ Force (N) = [[mass]] (kg) * 9.81 (acceleration due to Earth's gravity (msâ»Â²))

* Suggest to add an example to illustrate "distance", e.g.

`A b ^ B a`
b and B are 2 meters from the pivot.
a and A are 4 meters from the pivot.

Goal / Output / Stub generator
* Would "net moment" be a more appropriate term than "total moments" / "moments"?

Input
* Line 1: Please add "[[beam]]" after "String".

* Next n Lines: Please mention that "[[mass]] is a float and measured in kg."

Output
* Line 2: Please add "followed by the measurement unit {{N}}".

Constraints
* Please format "beam" as a [[variable]].

* Please delete "(kg)".

* Please add "in [[beam]]" after "( ^ )".

* Please add:
Each [[identifier]] appears in [[beam]] exactly once.
All [[identifier]]s are unique English letters.

Stub generator
* Please change Line 3 as:
loop n read identifier:word(1) mass:float

Thanks.

Damn, I'm still really bad at this ðŸ˜„

Added your changes, thanks as always!

Thanks for the comment, I either didn't get a notification for this or it was buried in others. I've decided to change it to round to integer instead. 

Due to the fair amount of required text to read, it'll be one less element to deal with.

# Ruby code for replicating the float arithmetic issue:

beam = gets.chomp
n = gets.to_i
array = []
n.times do
  identifier, mass = gets.split
  mass = mass.to_f
  array << [identifier, mass]
end
moment = array.sum{|i, m|
  (beam.index(i)-beam.index("^"))*9.81*m
}
puts moment == 0 ? "BALANCED" : "#{"ANTI-" if moment<0}CLOCKWISE"
puts "%.0fN" % moment.abs

That is annoying, sorry that happened...

I will take a look at changing the values slightly to ensure that doesn't happen!

Indeed it should be Nm, my mistake ðŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸

Nice, a simple fix for now would be to amend this line:
"The beam will be BALANCED if total clockwise moments equals total anti-clockwise moments."
To say:
"The beam will be BALANCED if total clockwise moments minus total anti-clockwise moments is zero (after rounding to nearest integer)."

But it would still be nice to have a test case that replicates the issue eventually, though it might be hard to create one.
The same thing happened to me during a clash today! Maybe you should remind the players to round the answer first before determining the direction of rotation.

That sucks.
I've added the simple edit of " (after rounding to nearest integer)." into the statement now as a quick fix, but it would be nice for a test case to be added that deals with this in the same way as the existing validator.

I have updated the incorrect validator and therefore removed the addition you made.

Apologies to both of you for it in the first place, I forgot to update the test case past the original comment.

Please give it another go with your codes and let me know if there are still any issues!

Ok, yeah. My code now passes all tests and validators.

I'd initially thought you were going to go the other way, where you would penalize players for not avoiding float arithmetic errors, but add a test case so they could debug it.

Now it seems you've just removed the tests that cause float arithmetic issues... hopefully that's true for other languages now too, I only checked in Ruby and Python.

Nah, it isn't bad, think of it as improving something good to be even better ðŸ˜‰

No problem!

Minor issue in the statement:
"The beam will be BALANCED if total clockwise moments equals total anti-clockwise moment."

"moments", then "equals", then "moment"â€¦
Updated! Changed slightly as I think it's easier to read and is consistent with the line below.
